trans-unit.source: InvokeMethod | Microsoft Docs
InvokeMethod
This sample shows the different ways of using the <xref:System.Activities.Statements.InvokeMethod> activity to invoke methods of a class.
A method belongs to a class and represents a contained set of operations.
The <xref:System.Activities.Statements.InvokeMethod> activity gives you the ability to call methods against objects or types, pass in parameters, and get the return value.
Methods can be invoked synchronously or asynchronously.
Sample Details
This sample uses the <xref:System.Activities.Statements.InvokeMethod> activity to perform the following scenarios:
Invoke an instance method without parameters.
Invoke an instance method with two parameters (<xref:System.String> and <xref:System.Int32>).
Invoke an instance method with two parameters (<xref:System.String> and <xref:System.Int32>) and a parameter array of type <xref:System.String>[].
Invoke an instance method with two parameters of type <xref:System.Int32> and a result of type <xref:System.Int32>.
In this scenario, the result value is bound to a variable and used in another activity.
It is displayed in the console using the <xref:System.Activities.Statements.WriteLine> activity.
Invoke a static method with two parameters of type <xref:System.String> and <xref:System.Int32>.
Invoke an instance method with one generic parameter of type <xref:System.String>.
Invoke a static method with two generic parameters of type <xref:System.String> and <xref:System.Int32>.
Invoke an instance method that has one parameter passed by reference of type <xref:System.String>.
In this scenario, the reference parameter is bound to a variable (`outParam`) and used in another activity.
It is displayed on the console using the <xref:System.Activities.Statements.WriteLine> activity.
Invoke an asynchronous instance method.
Invoke two different methods on the same instance of an object using two <xref:System.Activities.Statements.InvokeMethod> activities.
Store a value in an instance of an object.
Retrieve a value from an instance of an object.
To use this sample
This sample is provided in two versions.

The first version of this sample demonstrates the usage of <xref:System.Activities.Statements.InvokeMethod> through C# code using the [!INCLUDE[wf](../../../../includes/wf-md.md)] programming model and can be found under the CodedWorkflow\CS folder.
The second version demonstrates the usage of <xref:System.Activities.Statements.InvokeMethod> using XAML and can be found under the DesignerWorkflow\CS folder.
To run the coded workflow sample
Using [!INCLUDE[vs2010](../../../../includes/vs2010-md.md)], open the InvokeMethodUsage.sln solution file in the CodedWorkflow\CS folder.
To build the solution, press CTRL+SHIFT+B.
To run the solution, press CTRL+F5.
To run the designer workflow sample
Using [!INCLUDE[vs2010](../../../../includes/vs2010-md.md)], open the InvokeMethodUsage.sln solution file in the DesignerWorkflow\CS folder.
To build the solution, press CTRL+SHIFT+B.
To run the solution, press CTRL+F5.
The samples may already be installed on your machine.
Check for the following (default) directory before continuing.

If this directory does not exist, go to [Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) and Windows Workflow Foundation (WF) Samples for .NET Framework 4](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=150780) to download all [!INCLUDE[indigo1](../../../../includes/indigo1-md.md)] and [!INCLUDE[wf1](../../../../includes/wf1-md.md)] samples.
This sample is located in the following directory.
See Also
